title: Family Chronicle No. 1: Why A Newsletter
summary: First Family Chronicle newsletter (May 5, 1997) explaining the genealogical scope: Glendenning and Watling families, with ancestors including Harley, Peters, Sealey, Beattie, Rae, MacDonald, McAskill, MacNaughton, Leach, and Jardine. Don describes his 40+ year research beginning with his Great-Grandfather John Glendinning's family Bible (emigrated Scotland 1830). Provides earliest Glendinning information: John Glendinning born April 2, 1807 at Callister Hall, Scotland, married Margaret Harley August 23, 1833. Discusses Harley and Knowles connections, Peters lineage through his grandmother Elizabeth Peters Glendenning. Notes the striking pattern of few males in the Glendenning line producing male offspring. Shows Don's meticulous record-keeping and deep family knowledge from the project's inception.

The  Family  Chronicle

no.1										           1997 05 05   

Why A Newsletter




The Chronicle is an occasional Newsletter devoted to genealogy.  More specifically, it deals with the genealogy of my father, Elmer Alton Glendenning, and mother, Jane Elizabeth Jardine Watling.  It=s purpose is to both share and seek information.  It will be published from time to time as the spirit moves me.




In addition to Watling and Glendenning, my ancestors include people named Harley, Peters, Sealey, Beattie, Rae, MacDonald, McAskill, MacNaughton, Leach and Jardine.  And I am sure that there are others I have not discovered yet.




In order to provide a perspective, I may refer to people as my Grandfather, Walter Glendenning or my Great-grandmother, Elspeth Jardine etc. This intended to show both a relationship and to help position people by generation.




I believe my information to be accurate, however, there are likely some errors in what I have.  If you find any, please let me know; I will not be offended.  




I also need help in gathering information; my focus, is on information about earlier generations but I will take whatever you provide.  Reports of weddings, births and funerals often provide information about family connections.  Make a copy and send it along.   




Beginning The Search




I started gathering family tree information, on the Glendenning side, over forty years ago.  My first source was the family Bible of my Great-grandfather, John Glendinning, who emigrated from Scotland in 1830.  The Bible was passed down to my father. I also contracted with the Scottish Ancestry Research Society in Edinburgh, Scotland to do a search.




Later, I distributed a questionnaire to my aunts and uncles on my father=s side of the family.  Then there was a long period when I did nothing.  During the last decade I re-started the process with attention to my mother=s side. 




Much of the more recent information was gathered during conversations with family members...

title: Family Chronicle No. 2: Jardine Connection
summary: Second Family Chronicle (November 4, 1997) explores ancestral origins and family connections. Don notes a discrepancy regarding his Great-Grandmother—he believes it was Elspeth Jardine (not Elizabeth). Includes a 1991 Scot's Magazine letter from Denis Glendining about ancestors and historical records. Provides earliest documented family dates and discusses how many generations removed Don is from various ancestral lines (6th generation Glendenning, 5th generation Watling/MacDonald/MacAskill/MacNaughton/Leach/Rae, etc.). Fascinating section on "Wanderers" describing how many Glendennings and Watlings emigrated to Portland, Maine and other US locations in the early 1900s, including Don's parents' journey. Vividly describes Jane Watling (Don's mother) arriving in Portland January 24, 1908—the day Portland City Hall burned.

title: Family Chronicle No. 3: “Mac” MacDonald
summary: Third Family Chronicle (December 1, 1997) clarifies "Mac" MacDonald's full name as Hugh McGraw MacDonald (died 1914, Newcastle Bridge). Reports on a November 15 Watling descendants gathering at Black River with ~20 attendees sharing local history. Provides detailed land history of Alexander MacDonald property, noting his original grant and its subsequent division between children John and Jessie. Documents extensive Peters family information from Joy Glendenning Winton, including siblings of Don's grandmother Elizabeth Peters Glendenning. Updates on Jardine family genealogy and mentions Don's son Brian's correspondence with another Brian Glendenning in Australia. Includes information on other Glendinning families descended from Scottish emigration.

summary: Fifth Family Chronicle (October 31, 1998) analyzes Don's mother's autograph album, dating entries from 1910-1915. First entry: mother Jane Watling Glendenning, Portland Maine, December 1, 1910. Earliest entry by Don's father E. A. Glendenning from Wausau, Wisconsin, September 18, 1910 (before their marriage). Describes their wedding in New Brunswick October 18, 1910, followed by December 1910 Christmas entries in Bonny Eagle, Maine, and February 11, 1911 in Parksville, Tennessee (dam construction). Documents entries from family and friends from various locations including Tennessee, Nova Scotia, and Maine. title: Family Chronicle No. 6: CHRISTMAS ISSUE – 1998
summary: Sixth Family Chronicle (November 20, 1998) is a Christmas issue recounting Don's childhood Christmas memories at Black River. Vivid anecdotes: mother saying "Santa's birdie" was checking if children were being good; magic pantry drawer that produced extra goodies for visiting relatives; stockings with oranges, candy, nuts, pennies; sad memories of Uncle Chip dying suddenly Christmas Eve 1948 (heart attack while shopping), and two fatal car accidents (Earl Taylor 1969, Gerald and Elaine Taylor 1994). Positive gift memories include a wind-up caterpillar tractor and a train set. Notable entries: 1958 family trip to Florida with siblings in a new Buick; Christmas 1958 at home with homegrown meal; 1957 Christmas in Stamford, Connecticut when Don gave Carol (his wife) a diamond engagement ring. Reveals Don's warm family relationships and sentimental nature.

I=ve decided to make this my Christmas letter and, in it, to record, as best I can remember, some Christmas events and activities.  Memory plays tricks and so, the events and the dates my not be exactly as described by me or remembered by someone else.  Notes are written in the order that I recall them, not necessarily in the order in which they occurred.  In doing this, it is my hope that it will spark discussion about your own Christmas memories.  




The Little Birdie




As Christmas drew near, Mother had a favourite way of getting our attention and getting us to settle down.  She would say, AThere=s one of Santa=s birdies.@  Obviously, the birdie was checking to see if we were being good.  The birdie flitted up to or past the window.  By the time I turned to look, it was gone.  I never saw the birdie but Mother frequently did.  As I recall, it was only seen  during the evening or night.  That=s probably when the children got restless.




The Pantry




By the end of Christmas Day, the apples, oranges, nuts and candy would have been finished off.  Usually, on Christmas night some of the family not living at home would drop in.  Sometimes cousins would land along also.  Magically, extra goodies appeared during their visit.  It was only as I got older that I realized that the supply of goodies as kept in a drawer in the pantry.

title: Family Chronicle No. 7: Issue Number
summary: Seventh Family Chronicle (August 8, 1999) provides a comprehensive timeline of Don's parents' lives and work. Father (Elmer Alton Glendenning) born June 29, 1875; mother (Jane Elizabeth Watling) born February 28, 1890. Key dates: mother arrived Portland January 24, 1908 (Portland City Hall fire day); married October 18, 1910; worked Tennessee dam construction (Ocoee River dams 1911-1913); operated Little Branch Post Office November 1, 1914 to August 1, 1916; purchased multiple properties including Jessie MacDonald property July 21, 1914. Documents children's births: Grace (September 23, 1911), Walter (September 29, 1913), Venetia (May 14, 1915), Lillian (January 8, 1917). Notes Margaret Virginia died January 13, 1918 in Hampton, Virginia; John born December 14, 1919. Father died May 18, 1938 at home, buried May 21; mother died March 24, 1964 in Miramichi Hospital, buried March 28. Lists properties acquired and construction projects but notes many details lost to time.

title: Family Chronicle No. 8: Little Branch Post Office
summary: Eighth Family Chronicle (May 30, 1999) documents Little Branch Post Office history through archival records showing postmasters from 1871-1928, confirming Don's parents Elmer and Jane Glendenning served November 1, 1914 to August 1, 1916. Notes that Aunt Tine MacKenzie likely ran the post office in the Jessie MacDonald house 1902-1907 (between her husbands Tom Adams and John MacKenzie). Information about a separate Watling Post Office (1911-1928). Clarifies the Daly/Daley name change (Carson Daley changed spelling after WWII). Provides detailed genealogy of Aunt Tine's families: children from Tom Adams marriage (James, Jubal Willard, Gertrude) and from John MacKenzie marriage (Norman, Jean, Edith). Corrects earlier error: Alex MacDonald's first wife was Ethel MacTavish (not Catherine McGraw), second wife Beatrice Shuttleworth. Discusses cemetery records and the Alexander MacDonald property division.

title: Family Chronicle No. 10: Another Cousin
summary: Tenth Family Chronicle (December 1, 1999) uses Crown land grant records to document early settler families. Alexander McDonald Sr. granted Lot #2 (225 acres) June 3, 1812—property now owned by Norman Glendenning. Lists other original grantees (Sinclair, Fowlie families) with acreages and dates. References "Pioneers of the Bay Chaleur" showing John Glendinning purchased Lot #7 in Salmon Beach (granted to Fidele and Joseph Arceneau 1812), sold 1855 to Abram Buttimer, and received Canobie land grant 1868. Documents land grants to Glendenning males: John Glendinning Jr. (Canobie, Lot #31, August 17, 1868), Walter Glendenning (Canobie, Lot #30, February 17, 1873), Atton E. Glendenning (Canobie, Lot #28, July 6, 1901). Notes unusual practice: settlers often occupied land years before receiving title. Mentions FWH's "Boyhood Memories of New Brunswick" (c. 1940) manuscript at Mount Allison University describing Canobie life. Queries about Miller's Bridge origin and other local place names.

There were over 600,000 Canadians overseas during WW1.  Most served in the Canadian Expeditionary Force; many served in the British army.  The Canadian Archives has developed a database of most but not all of the names.  For anyone wishing to search, the web site is Awww.archives.ca@  A search revealed 10 Glendennings including (Uncle) Guy Wellington Glendenning (Regimental Number 445210) and (Aunt) Margaret Violet Glendenning (No Regimental Number - she was a nurse) There also were 16 Glendinnings.  




There were 21 Watlings including (Uncle) Donald Ernest Watling.  (#70039) The other Watlings which could have been related include Archie (#46798), George Maxwell (#901129), William Jubal (#832788)




Home Children




The Home Children listed on the Internet include 1 Glendenning and 5 Watlings.




Another uncle?




My search of the NB Archives turned up a Walter Glendenning born April 19, 1881 to Walter Glendenning and Elizabeth Peters.  At first I thought that Dad had another brother, however, the month and year, but not the date, matches that of Uncle Leonard.  My conclusion is that either someone copied the names and dates incorrectly, that they had trouble deciding on a name, or that they actually named him Walter and changed the name later. 




Refrigeration




Some time ago I told you my story about our new refrigerator; more recently, Loisanne mentioned getting a new fridge.  




Refrigeration at home, as I remember it, was the basement floor.  Butter and milk were kept in the basement; the butter in a crock and the milk, probably in a shortening bucket with a lid and presumably cream for our strawberries..  Inevitably, or so it seemed to me, I was the one who had to go down to the basement for the milk and butter.

I found it especially interesting to hear some of the Ayoung folks@ reminiscing; I would like to have heard them talk when the older folk were not around.

Spring




I forgot to look to see if the spring still flows on the side of the road down the hill from the concrete post?  Horses were taken there for water, cows were herded there once a day for water, I believe that one calf met its end there, and even passers by used it.  The water ran from the spring down to the brook.




As I recall, it had a box around it about 3 feet square; I do not recall a lid.  The box is gone but does the spring still flow?

Home-made Saw




Winter was the time to cut wood, not only for our own use but to sell; we usually sold 24' furnacewood.  The yard above the house would have a huge pile left in long lengths.  In the spring, the wood cutter would be set up to cut the wood into stove (16 in.) or furnace (24 in.) lengths.  Logs too large to be wrestled to the table of the wood-cutter, were cut with a cross-cut saw.




I do not know where all the wood was sold but for about 20 years several cord of wood was sold to Vince Flaherity in Loggieville.  Dad also sold wood to the Branch school.  The story is told that Dad had sold a set number of cords of wood to the Branch school for a number of years and at the end of each school year there was a bit more left over than was the case the previous year.  Then the contract was changed to another supplier for the same number of cords.  Gradually the surplus was used up and the number of cords per year had to be increased.




In early years the wood was hauled by sled or wagon; later a truck was hired to take the wood to Loggieville.  I recall one fall day when the truck was being loaded, the driver saying@you=re being too honest@ with your measure.




Walter and John would go to the woods and cut, split and load a half cord on each of two sleds; the next day, they would deliver the wood to Chatham or Loggieville  - two men, two horses, two days plus the value of the wood for $5.  Walter also told me about he and Dad coming out from the woods in late afternoon with a load of wood when the wagon broke (I cannot recall what part broke).   They unhitched the team and came on home for supper; later that night, they returned to the woods and Walter held the lantern while Dad cut a tree and fixed the wagon.

title: Family Chronicle No. 15: Alexander MacDonald
summary: Fifteenth Family Chronicle (December 7, 2000) documents deaths and life histories from newspaper records and church documents. Alexander MacDonald (1843 death notice, age 68): native of Assynt Parish, Rosshire, Scotland, emigrated 1803, died October 31 of dropsy after 8-month illness, leaving wife Grace MacAskill, two sons, six daughters. Grace (MacAskill) MacDonald (1874 death): widow, age 93, native of Co. Sutherland, Scotland, emigrated 1803, died February 23. Elspeth (Jardine) MacDonald (Don's Great-Grandmother): died September 12, 1907 of "debility," buried St. Stephen's Cemetery (husband John MacDonald presumed buried there but unconfirmed). Jubal and Grace (MacDonald) Watling: Jubal died February 19, 1915 (Gazette); Grace died September 28, 1934 (Chatham Gazette). Grace's funeral account: conducted by three ministers, pallbearers included Norman MacKenzie, Walter Glendenning, Gordon MacNaughton, Alex Newton, Jubal Dickson, James Jardine. Interment St. Stephen's Cemetery. Jessie MacDonald documented as Third Class Teacher, District 11, Parish of Chatham (April-June 1860); school register shows 38 pupils; contract with trustees from October 15, 1858 Napan. Donald Ernest Watling: St. Stephen's records show Donald Cameron Watling born February 23, 1892—Uncle Ern's birthday.

AOn the 31st of October, of dropsy, after an illness of eight months, which he here with truly Christian resignation to the divine will, Mr. Alexander MacDonald, of Little Branch, Black River, in the 68th year of his age, thus leaving a disconsolate wife, in the evening of her days, two sons and six daughters, to mourn the loss of an affectionate husband and tender father.  He calmly resigned his spirit into the hands of his Maker, in the firm hope of blessed immortality.  ABlessed are they who die in the Lord.=




Mr. MacDonald was a native of the Parish of Assynt, Rosshire, Scotland and emigrated to this country in the year 1803.@




Recently I checked the internet and found Assynt to be a Parish in Rosshire, Scotland.  It is located in the northern part of Scotland along the west coast and includes many islands.  Grace MacAskill, his wife, came from Sutherland County which adjoins Rosshire.  Both counties are extremely hilly and rocky with many inlets and streams, and with little in the way of agricultural land.

William McChesney, Carol=s GGGG Grandfather, was born in Scotland and came to Maryland about 1740.  His son, Benjamin, seems to have used the name Chesney and not McChesney.  Later Chesneys lived in Virginia before moving to Illinois between 1831 when he was born and 1856 when he married Huldah Desiree Merritt.




Theodore Kaifer, Carol G Grandfather, was born in Germany in 1825 and moved to Illinois before 1855 when his daughter, Mary Anita, was born.




J.J. Frank, another GGG Grandfather was born in Rinich, Bavaria on April 24, 1734.  His son, John Jacob and Grandson, Henry, were both born in Bavaria;  the Grandson came to Illinois between 1834 when he was born and 1863 when he was married.  




Lincoln Connection




Family lore says that Carol=s Grandmother, Flora Elizabeth Murphy, was a cousin of Abraham Lincoln.













American Revolution




Carol=s GGG Grandfather, Benjamin Chesney  enlisted as a soldier in the ARevolutionary War@ (against Britain) in May, 1775 and served for 6 years.  He was in a number of battles in Maryland including Brandywine, Stony Point, and  Guildford  Courthouse.  (There are other names of skirmishes but I cannot decipher them.)  He was wounded in the leg.




In 1818 he petitioned for, and was granted, a pension of eight dollars a month.  In his petition, he states that he did not receive discharge papers because his officer did not have money to buy paper and that he was disabled and could not make a living.

The previous newsletter listed names of relatives who served in a branch of the military.  In this news letter, I decided to jot down some wartime recollections.  I recognize that what I say may not even be accurate but these jottings are my recollections.  These notes are in random order.




I was age 10 when war was declared.  I recall  discussions in the schoolyard about the war and if we might be attacked.




We were encouraged to save old newspapers and tin foil (?).  We bought loose tea in packages with metallic (lead) covering.  We always saved the lead.  I recall this material stacked in the entry way of the Little Branch school.




Ken had gone to Moncton to enlist.  He phoned Mother to say that he would be passing through Newcastle that night on his way to Toronto.  Walter (?) drove Mum to Newcastle to see Ken on the way through.




I was in the Miramichi Rural on June 6, 1944 when a car came to the school to pick up Francis MacNaughton.  His father was killed on D-Day in the Normandy landing.  A hush fell over the school and the school bus later in the afternoon..




Vance MacNaughton said that he was in the Little Branch School on  May 8, 1945 when the school door flew open.  My mother entered unannounced to shout to all that the war was over in Europe.




Some items were rationed including sugar and sugar products, oil, gas, butter, tea (?).  We had our coupon books and a coupon was removed every time we made a purchase.  Because we lived on a  farm and there were a number in the family, rationing was never a problem.  For a while John had a big truck and therefore had extra stamps for gasoline.

title: Family Chronicle No. 26: My search for Watling roots has been less extensive than that on the Glendenning side, nevertheless,
content_preview:
The Family Chronicle

No.26										    July 9, 2002

My search for Watling roots has been less extensive than that on the Glendenning side, nevertheless, I will record what I have and add as time and energy permit.  Some time ago, Edith (MacKenzie) Schickle gave me a copy of information given to her by Ernie Watling.  Much of the information which follows comes from that source although I have been able to augment it from other sources.




Origin of Name




The first record of the name was found in Sussex, England somewhere between London and Dover.  It is likely that the name arises from Wartling which was a hamlet in the area but others believe that it was associated with Watling Road, the great Roman Road, which started near Dover, passed through Canterbury , turned north at London and went as far as St Albans     It is thought, that the Watlings were Vikings who landed in Northern Scotland in 870 AD, invaded northern France in 910 AD and then came to England with William the Conqueror in 1066.  The name is found in the Domesday Book which was a census taken in England in 1086.




By the time of Richard 1, the Watling name had spread north to Watlingford in Oxfordshire, Watlington in Norfolk, Essex and Hertfordshire.  Many Norman families moved north to Scotland in the 12th century and this may have included some Watlings.




Watling is thought to share the same roots as Whatling, Watlington, Watlingtone, Whatlington, Whatlingtone, Wadling, and Wadlingdon.  Over time, the name spread into the northern parts of England and to Scotland as well.

Kinsmen of the family Watling who came to North America include Ffrances Watling who settled in Virginia in 1660, John Watling who landed in America in 1753, James Watling settled in Philadelphia in 1842 and Mary Watlington who settled in Antigua in 1679.  Some Watlings moved to...

The lamp is lit in the window

And back of it is her chair

And as I look across, it seems

She surely must be there.




I picture too her little room

So very neat and snug

Her very fingers made it so

Oh yes, the braided rug.

I pull apart the curtains

Her dresses hung up neatly

Yes, as neatly as can be.




And as I sit and ponder

A picture there I see

It’s of my Mother’s Mother

Whose room it used to be




Yes, patient, tireless Mother

Who gave to their world their best

Your children call you blessed

God’s love made manifest.




And when my work on earth is done

And I have crossed the Bar

God grant that I may enter in

Where those dear Mothers are.

The Muddy Trail




Both Jack Wilson and my brother, Ken, tell me that the poem, The Muddy Trail, printed in the last Chronicle was written by Murdoch Sullivan who lived on the South Side of Black River.  According to Jack, the poem was likely written between 1968 and 1974 when the road was paved.  After the road was paved, Murdoch wrote the following piece of poetry.




The Road We Long Waited for come At Last




It happened in the summer

Of nineteen seventy-four,

When the gravel it rushed down the south-side,

Just like the Tidal Bore.




Some folks they were smiling,

And others were afraid,

That it was just an election dodge,

But the hard-top it was laid.




They built it high, they made it wide,

It is Black River's pride,

The folks all say they're on Broadway,

When they come down the south-side.




For long years we have waited,

Many dollars they've been spent,

But I never thought that I would live

To see this great event.




For many years I've walked this road,

Many times I can recall,

The muddy road that we once knew-

We had to face it, spring and fall.




But those days they are all past and gone,

Like the morning dew has fled,

As we look into the future

For the years that lie ahead.




So here are cheers to all the boys,

Our truckmen one and all,

For the muddy trail will ne'er prevail,

When the big rains come this fall.

Follow-up




Following some items in Issue 31, Jack Wilson tells me that he purchased some items from a sale at the John W. MacNaughton property including a octagonal plant stand inscribed on the; under side “Fraser MacKay, June 22, 1944”.  I think that was the year Fraser graduated.




Plant stands were a standard shop project.  There are probably not many homes in Black River today without one.  If my memory serves me right, they were octagonal, eight and certainly no more than 10 inches across, had four legs and stood about 24 to 26 inches tall.  Most were finished with shellac and varnish; some may have been stained – usually walnut.




My brother Ken reminded me that my little red tractor did not come from Santa after all.  It was a gift from one of the “MacDonald Sisters” probably Frances and may have been a thank you for the milk which we delivered to them while they were in residence in Black River.  They lived in Portland but usually summered in the old home, the Ken MacDonald place, on the spot where Cameron Macdonald now lives.  (Ken’s Hill originated from the fact that Ken MacDonald owned the property and lived nearby.)




I appreciate hearing recently from Robin Farrell, a first Cousin once removed, (figure that out) now living with his family in Rochester, New York.)




The Electric Iron




During the first years of their married life, Dad worked at construction sites, usually dam sites as far as I know.  Some of the sites had electricity, probably to power some of the equipment but also available to the homes where the families lived.  As a result, Mum had an electric iron among things stored in the closet at the head of the stairs (the equivalent of the attic in novels and movies).  Sometimes on a stormy wintry day, I was allowed to root aroun...

Donna (Russell) Goodfellow confirms that their flinch Game came from my sister, Grace.  I must now conclude that Flinch was a game unique to our family.  Parker Brothers still sells the game; I bought two games yesterday.




Dorothy (MacKay) Lind wondered about Ken’s Hill.  As one left the Little Branch School heading for Loggieville, one passed the Jim Finno property.  It was a large two-story home in a long lane and near the river.  From the turn to the brook was what we called the “Finno property.”  Dad had bought it from Jim Finno many years ago.  Still traveling towards Loggieville, one climbed “Ken’s Hill”.  On the right, towards the shore, stood the Ken MacDonald house.  Further along, still on the right hand side of the road, was a small bungalow built originally, I believe, by Weldon MacDonald.  Ken and Cameron MacDonald were Weldon’s sons.  As a matter of interest, Cameron retired back to Black River and built a home on the hill where the Ken MacDonald property once stood.




I’ve also heard the breakfast story.  During a health class, the teacher was asking students what they had for breakfast.  Ken is reported to have said “Some mornings we have porridge and some mornings we have "slipgut”,  Slipgut was a term used for porridge made from home grown wheat ground into flour.  (At one time there was a gristmill up the Branch but in my time, grain was taken to the “Monks” in Rogersville to be ground)

Selkirk Settlers




My cottage is on a peninsula overlooking Orwell Bay where, 200 years ago, the Selkirk Settlers landed on PEI.  These were not the only Selkirk settlers, but I believe that they were the first.  The notes that follow are based on an article in the Charlottetown Guardian on August 2, 2003.




Thomas Douglas, Earl of Selkirk, brought 800 settlers into this area in 1803.  Most of them came from the Isles of Skye and Rassay off the north west coast of Scotland.  Interestingly, this is the same year that Alexander MacDonald, my Great Grandfather, arrived in this country.




“In the mythology, Highlanders left Scotland because they were cleared off the land by landlords who wanted to raise sheep.  But the reality of the story is more complicated.  At the time, their landlord, Baron MacDonald of Slate was doing three things.  He was auctioning off leases on the Scottish tenants lands.  Rents were going up and he was starting to move tenants to new land.  




As well, MacDonald was trying to raise a regiment of Highland soldiers for the British army and was disappointed that the volunteer rate was low.  And so he was basically threatening the families on his estates that if they did not supply younger sons for his regiment, they would face the consequences.  The backdrop is the collapse of the clans in Scotland.”




I am sure that much of what was faced by the Selkirk settlers applied to our ancestors 







as well, many of who came to Canada about the same time.

title: Family Chronicle No. 50: The Grain Harvest
content_preview:
The Family Chronicle

The Grain Harvest




When PEI set up its museum system, it established a number of small museums instead of a single large one.  Consequently there is a museum devoted to fisheries, agriculture, ship building, etc.  The agricultural museum is at Orwell corner – a community founded by Selkirk settlers 200 years ago.  Actually the land around a crossroads was taken over and maintained to show how people lived 150 ears ago and has a country store, school, church, blacksmith shop, community hall, etc.  




Orwell Corner is near our cottage so recently I went with a friend to see a grain harvesting demonstration.  Of course, it brought back boyhood memories.




Binding Grain  




We had a binder for cutting grain; a binder differed from a reaper in that a binder tied the grain in sheaves whereas a reaper simply cut the grain and swept it off in bunches.  The binder was hauled by a team of 2 and sometimes four horses.  The cutter blade cut the grain and there were rakes which rotated and pushed the cut grain on to a moving horizontal canvas.   A binder had three canvases stretched between rollers – a horizontal one and two at a 45-degree angle.  Canvases had to be tightened from time to time and were always loosened at the end of the day.  Seems to me that the binder was always covered with a tarp at the end of the day to protect the canvas from the weather.




The horizontal canvas moved the grain until it was caught up between two vertical ones 







which carried the grain to the assembly where the grain was tied with a piece of “binder twine”.  (Brantford Twine Co. from Brantford, Ontario.)  After being tied, the sheaf was kicked off the binder onto the ground.  Heavy or damp grain would sometimes jam the canvasses.

title: Family Chronicle No. 51: John Franklin Glendenning (December 14, 1919 – June 21, 1986)
summary: Biography of John Franklin Glendenning (Dec 14, 1919 – June 21, 1986), Don's brother. Major contributor to farm labor after father's illness; worked delivering fish, cutting wood, pressing hay, and trucking goods. Took agricultural course in Newcastle (1930s) including mechanics and woodworking; built a tractor with Brydone Weeks from car and truck parts without welding equipment. Met Mary Edna Bessie Watling at church; married Jan 27, 1944; had four children. Opened store in their living room (1948), later built proper store with gas tanks (1968). Entrepreneurial spirit; turned down military service due to poor eyesight but farming was essential service. Known for singing hymns while working. Published October 16, 2003.

title: Family Chronicle No. 52: ________________ Birthdays
summary: Celebrates 90th birthdays of first cousins Guy Edwin Glendenning (April 15, 1913) and George Elbridge Watling (Nov 24, 1913). Guy grew up in Canobie, son of George Raymond Glendenning and Hilda Ellis (one of 13 children); married Verna Daley; worked at Bathurst paper mill; operates maple sugar business in retirement. Includes detailed genealogical charts for both cousins spanning multiple generations with birth dates, marriages, and offspring. Notes Guy still active in lodge, drives ATV, attends Napan Fair. Emphasizes the importance of documenting extended family information and invites corrections. Published November 10, 2003.

I have not been reporting family events although I thought this time I would make an exception.  A couple of first cousins are celebrating 90th birthdays, however, so I’ve decided to wish them a Happy Birthday.  (I am taking these notes from memory so will apologize in advance for any errors.)  If there are other cousins who have reached this milestone, please let me know.




My oldest living first cousin, I think, is Guy Edwin Glendenning who celebrated his 90th birthday on April 15.  According to my records, he is the oldest male Glendenning that ever lived.  Guy grew up in Canobie and is the son of George Raymond Glendenning and Hilda Ellis.  He is one of thirteen children.  Although his father worked for a while in Portland, Maine, I believe all the children were born in Canobie where he farmed.  Guy married Verna Daley and they had six children.




Guy was one of the first settlers in Springfield, a new settlement back of Canobie.  Guy worked at the paper mill in Bathurst.  In retirement, he had a maple sugar operation, now operated by the next generation, works around his farm and still attends lodge.  He enjoys his new truck.  Recently my brother, Ken, visited Guy and Verna and Guy took him on his ATV to visit the maple syrup operation.  Guy still visits the Napan Agricultural Fair and drops in at Norman and Kenneth’s for a brief visit.  The following is the lates information on Guy’s family.  Please let me know of changes or corrections.

Visited New Bandon Cemetery where grandfather Walter and wife Elizabeth Peters are buried. Discusses slovens (low-platform farm wagons used for heavy items like barrels and threshers)—George Adams owned one in Black River and Don recalls another in Canobie. Miramichi Visit

I am interested in all the early settlers of Black River even though they may not be ancestors.  I still have many gaps but Ernie MacLean provided me with background on the MacLean families.     




Ken and I made a trip to the Bathurst area to visit relatives including Guy Glendenning who I mentioned in an earlier newsletter.  Also stopped at the New Bandon Cemetery where my grandfather, Walter, and his wife, Elizabeth Peters, are buried.  Also buried in the New Bandon Cemetery are Grand-father’s brother, John and John’s wife Ellen Dickey.  I have not been able to find where my Great Grandfather and Grandmother, John and Margaret Glendinning, are buried.  Also had a brief visit with Marion Glendenning and Carson Daley.  So it was a good day although a couple of others we normally visit were not at home when we stopped by.  Had a visit with Sandra (Taylor) Shea on the way home.

	Winter Storms				
	



	
	
      
	

	



	
	



	
	
Harold
	MacDonald’s Truck – Feb. 1952
	



	
	
     
	

	



	
	



	
	
Norman’s
	truck – 1952, probably in March
	
       
	
	
   
	
	
The
	Maritimes, especially Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island, have
	been inundated with snow in recent weeks.  I am reminded of similar
	winters in the Miramichi when I was a youngster.
	



	
	
Before
	the advent of snow ploughs, after a winter storm, the men of the
	community would hitch their horses to sleds and break the road. 
	Breaking the road meant putting a 
	
	



	
	



	
	



	
	
first
	track through the deep snow.  One team would make a track through
	the snow for a ways then another team would take a turn.  If the
	roads were badly drifted, sometimes a track would be made through
	the woods at the edge of the road.  A couple of the worst spots for
	snow were “Ken’s Hill” and at the Middle Black River School. 
	Because roads were often below the level of the fields, the “gut”
	would drift full.  The other common problem was when several storms
	with high winds occurred close together and the road drifted full
	each time after it was ploughed.
	



	
	
As
	roads were rebuilt, ditches were deepened, road surfaces were raised
	so snow would blow off, wooden fences were removed or replaced to
	reduce the build up of snow and snow fences were erected in fields
	parallel to the road to catch the snow
	



	
	
Later
	years also brought better snow removal equipment.  The earliest I
	remember were the road graders and the crawler tractors.  The

Glenelg
	in geography is one of the most common palindromes, a  name that
	reads the same backwards and forwards. The original Glenelg in the
	highlands of Scotland is both a village and a mountainous peninsula
	and a bay in Ross-Shire that look across the Sound of Sleat to the
	Isle of Skye.  This highland name Glenelg is said to derive from the
	Gaelic Gleann Seilg, the Glen of Hunting.  
	
	



	
	
There
	are many other Glenelgs, including  a Glenelg village and lake in
	Nova Scotia, and a Glenelg in Ontario.  In the 1830's Lord Glenelg
	was England's Secretary of State for the Colonies; and his name
	commonly appears on Australian and New Zealand rivers and street
	signs. 
	
	



	
	
Our
	Glenelg Parish is "So named for the native place in Scotland of

	settled there about 1790."*

Elmer
	Glendenning (1875-1938) and Franklin Glendenning (1876-1937). 
	Thanks Loisanne.
	
 
	
Building
	a Load of Hay
	
 
	
There
	was quite an art to building a load of loose hay – and remember,
	the load was being build on a rack on a truck wagon.  For those not
	familiar with a truck wagon, it was a heavy farm wagon with high
	wheels.  The hayrack sat about three feet off the ground which meant
	that you had to pitch the hay a minimum of four feet before putting
	it on the rack and another 6-8 feet when it was loaded.  The rack
	had a bit of a well because the sides were built up to clear the
	wagon wheels.
	
 
	

	The hay would be forked onto the
	wagon.  The first forkfuls were tramped well in the centre of the
	rack.  Then forkfuls of hay were placed around the perimeter.  The
	key was to keep placing lots of hay along the outside and then
	binding it by adding hay to the middle.  The sides of a load of hay
	were kept higher than the middle.  Otherwise, the hay on the sides
	would just keep slipping off.  
	
	

	 
	

	A well-built load of hay would
	be about 7 feet high above the rack with the sides kept straight. 
	It was important to have a solid load because many times it would be
	taken across a rough field and then a mile or two by road before
	reaching home.
	

	 
	

	Once home, a load of hay would
	be driven into the barn and, if at night, the horses unhitched,
	taken out through a back door and stabled for the night.  Otherwise,
	the horses would remain hitched to the wagon while the hay was
	unloaded.  It was harder to stick the fork into a load that was left
	over night.

Rubber
	boots were standard wear around the barn (Work boots were for

	were standard wear for fall, winter and spring.  They were made like

	winter and wet feet soon smelled.

	recall my real leather winter boots, which laced up and were higher
	than gumboots.  The snow and wet were hard on them and one treated
	them regularly with a paste wax – Skowhegan, as I recall.  This

	Notes for JUBAL
	WATLING:
	

	Recent information from a number of sources cause me to make a
	number of changes in information about Jubal and his immediate
	family. While I found some Watlings in PEI, based on my examination

The Dump Cart
	


	



	
	


	



	
	
I
	have fond memories, but cannot tell you why, of the lowly dumpcart -
	the workhorse of a small farm.  It was used for hauling gravel,
	banking, turnips, manure, firewood, etc, etc, etc. – and of
	course, people.  As the name says, it was a cart that dumped; while
	loading was difficult, unloading was easy.
	



	
	
One
	sat at the front with one’s feet resting on a shaft along the side
	of the horse.  The horse’s rump was only a few 
	
	
inches
	from the cart box.  A cart was a bit heavy to lift when hitching a
	horse but much easier to back up than a wagon.  To unload, one
	simply undid a latch at the front and lifted; gravity did the rest. 
	I especially remember using a dump cart when harvesting turnips
	(before we had a small truck).  The horse walked between two rows of
	turnips, and the cart straddled them.  One pulled a turnip, cleaned
	and topped it and threw it into the cart.  
	
	



	
	
When
	the cart was full, one drove to the house.  If the turnips were
	destined for the basement, they had to be unloaded one by one and
	dropped down the chute.  If unloaded on the barn floor, the cart
	could simply be dumped.
	



	
	
Don
	Edge writes:
	



	
	
“Interestingly,
	the Bay du Vin is described as the "windy river," after
	the notion it is not named after wine, since no grapes grew there,
	and that the name comes from Baie
	des Ventes,
	Bay of Winds. However, a very early map (reproduced in Ganong)
	identifies the area as Baie
	des Ovines
	or Sheep Bay. I think this last is the more likely origin of what we
	call Bay du Vin.

“Twitchin
	 logs”
	



	
	
Reading
	W. D. Hamilton’s book on the
	Old North Esk
	reminded me of  terms used in lumbering.  While my woods work was
	limited to cutting our winter’s wood or a bit extra for sale, my
	father, like many New Brunswickers, had lumbered   in New Hampshire
	and probably Maine.  Several of my brothers also had spent the
	winter in the woods mostly up the Miramichi.
	



	
	
Based
	on Hamilton’s book and my own knowledge, there were “choppers”
	who felled trees and, in earlier days, squared the timber 
	
	



	
	
with
	their axes; “swampers” who cleared roads or paths to move the
	logs; “teamsters” who moved the logs using oxen or horses; logs
	were “twitched” meaning that they were dragged individually from
	where they were felled to where the sled was stationed; “yarding”
	meant that they were twitched to a common area, a yard, where they
	were piled for later transportation; one used a chain for twitching
	with the chain fastened to the log directly or using a set of grips
	– like heavy ice tongs which dug deeper when the hauling was
	heavy.

	often had to be “skidded” which meant using skids as ramps in
	order to pile logs on top of each other.  We also used skids to put

	each other with runners or smaller pieces between layers.  Skids
	would be placed between the log on the ground and the top of the
	load forming a ramp.  A “piling chain” was placed around the log

I wrote to you some while back about my Mother, Eva Peters, who had done a history correspondence course when she was in her late 60's back in 1984.  She had never gone beyond Grade 8 in her small school in Clifton (high school required room and board in Bathurst, which her family could not afford).  However, in her later years she restarted her education, beginning with Grade 9 History, at which she excelled.  I used to tease her that she was not learning so much as remembering!  She relied a lot on her early memories of growing up on the North Shore, and her essays were filled with references to those times.  Her teacher enjoyed reading her work too, and even had one essay published in "The Correspondent", which was produced by the Ministry of Education here in Ontario.

The First Black River Community Hall




















































Did you know that the present Black River Community Hall is the third building on the same site?




Like most communities of the day, schools in Black River served as centers for community gatherings.  My sister, Lillian, recalled many dances in the Little Branch School at which my father volunteered to sell candy and pop, take tickets, and help with setting up and cleaning up afterwards.  Many others in the community, I know, could say the same about their parents and neighbours at their local school.  




This changed in 1931 with the opening of the Black River Community Hall on the same site as the current building.  Most of the information that follows was gleaned and interpreted from The Book of Accounts for the Black River Community hall for the period 1930 to 1973.










Discussion about a community hall, I am sure, consumed considerable time in the community.  In any case, on October 20, 1930, the first loads of gravel and sand were taken to the site by George Cameron, A. W. MacDougall, Harold Godfrey and Robert Harper.  Wallace MacDonald worked that day but did not haul gravel. Forms were built on October 21 and 22 and on October 23 and 24 concrete was poured.  A dream began to take shape.




A week later a crew of carpenters gathered and began to frame the new building.  Three weeks later, the structure was closed in including, I believe, shingles on the roof   Neighbours engaged in carpentry included George Godfrey, Alfred MacLean, James Mortimer, Elmer Glendenning, Harold Godfrey, Ian MacNaughton, Ian Mortimer, Bert Gibson and Sinclair Williston.   Not all mentioned above worked every day; others not named also worked but apparently not at carpentry.  On November 13, 1930, the building was closed in including shingles on the...

	Fowlie at Fowlie’s Mill in 1940; courtesy of Everard MacLean
	



	
	

	 MacNaughton
	



	
	
My
	thanks to Thomas Holme for the following note, which arose from his
	reading of an item in Family Chronicle No. 28:
	



	
	
“There were no McNaughtons living in Dunderave
	castle after around 1720. Your website states that Malcolm's son
	John was born in Dunderave castle July 24, 1774. But the
	MacNaughtons lost the castle and all their lands in the first decade
	of the 1700s. By 1711 they final paperwork was finished and
	Dunderave no longer belonged to them. Dunderave belonged to the
	family of Campbel of Ardkinglas that lived across loch Fyne from the
	MacNauchtans. We are sure that a few members of the MacNauchtan
	family continued to dwell in the castle for 

perhaps another
	ten years in hope that some way would develop to return the lands
	and castle to the MacNauchtans. But that did not happen. Famous
	historians living in that time write that the castle was abandoned
	and 
	
	
none of the MacNauchtan family lived there
	afterwards. So you see, he couldn't 

have been born in
	Dunderave in 1774”.




	
	
Darts
	



	
	
We
	sometimes played darts.  Not having a proper cork dartboard, we
	played against a barn door or wood wall. Neither did we have darts
	so we made our own.
	



	
	
To
	make a dart, one followed these easy steps:

ST PAUL’S PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH

BLACK RIVER BRIDGE, NB

Speaking Notes on the occasion of the75th Anniversary*

July 24, 2005




Congratulations - 	members and adherents of this congregation for seventy-five years of dedication and service

Thanks for the invitation to take part 

Seventy-five years ago	- first regular church service.  

- I was here and let me see -  - Edith, Blanche, Marjorie, George, Ken, Norm, Marion,  others ?




The Chatham Gazette on July 15, 1930 called this church building “a fine and beautiful edifice.  It is a credit to any community.”




The article went on to say:

“In these days when any kind of building may pass for a church, it can be truly said that the structure in Black River reflects the ideal ecclesiastical architecture for a small house of worship.  The church has evoked nothing but praise from all who have seen it.  Great appreciation is expressed to all who have worked to make it what it is – to the building committee, to the carpenters in charge and others who o have laboured without stint.”  




And I would commend all who worked diligently since to maintain it.

First some comments about the year 1930:

Black River, like the rest of Canada, was in recession.  There was little or no cash; it was a barter economy.  

Families spent much effort just putting food on the table, planting, cultivating, harvesting, preserving and storing for the winter.

Telephone service had not yet arrived

Most travel was by horse and wagon or horse and sled;

There were a few cars but many were stored in barns for lack of funds to buy gas

Social gatherings were held at either the church or the school

The community hall was still in the discussion stage

On Reaching 100




Yes, this is Issue 100.  Reaching 100 was never an objective but has become a milestone and, I think, therefore, is worthy of reflection.  Issue No. 1, on May 5, 1997 stated:




“The Chronicle is an occasional Newsletter devoted to genealogy… Its purpose is to both share and seek information.  It will be published from time to time as the spirit moves me…



Background




I had started gathering information about the Glendenning side of my family some fifty years ago.  My starting point was a Bible belonging to my Great-Grandfather, John Glendinning, who emigrated from Scotland in 1830.  Next, I contacted the Scottish Ancestry Research Society in Edinburgh, Scotland. Later, I distributed a questionnaire to my aunts and uncles on my father’s side of the family.  




Then, followed a long period during which I did very little except maintain my database.  On reaching retirement age, I picked up the threads and began gathering information again. I now had information to share with siblings when we met.  Siblings were, or seemed to be, interested in the information, so I developed the Family Chronicle devoted, as noted above, to spreading information about my family especially ancestors. 




Later I began to share information to my extended family and friends via Email.  More recently, my son, Brian, established a website, provided space and offered upload all issues.  I stopped distributing by Email.    




A while back, I made a conscious effort to add recollections of life in Black River when I was growing up.  I seldom research a topic; I write as the spirit moves me.  Sometimes on reading earlier articles, I wish that I had provided more in some articles.  Maybe I will reprint and elaborate on some of the topics.

The Family Chronicle

No. 106									     October 24,2005

A Recollection by Donald Edge




The Outhouse




"And it shall come to pass, that instead of sweet smell there shall be stink…"

[Isaiah 3:24]




My grandparents' house saw many firsts.  It was the first house in Upper Black River to have a telephone, the first to have electricity, the first to have running hot water, and the first to have an indoor toilet.  Of course the toilet and the light bulbs and the hot water depended on the electricity, and that came from a generator that rarely worked.  Thus we basked in firsts but like everyone else in Black River we used kerosene lamps and bathed in a bathtub filled by lugging up stairs water heated in the kitchen wood stove. Youngsters weren't worth the lugging, and were thought to have not much dignity, and so late on Saturdays they were bathed in a zinc washtub set in the middle of the kitchen floor, youngest first.  




In the most private of moments everyone resorted to an outdoor privy and chamber pots. Chamber pots could be quite fancy.  Every home in Black River had one or more wash stands, each containing a small bowl for washing, a water pitcher, a wastewater bowl, and a chamber pot.  Today these are just for show, but when I was a boy these were the hallmarks of a well kept home and a public display that cleanliness is next to Godliness. Given the circumstances and the equipment, we were about as clean as could be expected.  For that matter, we were probably about as Godly as could be expected, all things considered.

I was always too young to be trusted with carrying a brimming chamber pot downstairs and outside to wherever filled pots went to, and so I know nothing about that end of the business, nor to this day do I care to.

summary: Family Chronicle Issue 112 (February 23, 2006): Profiles first cousins Venetia Glendenning Russell, Marjorie Watling Young, Edith MacKenzie Shickel, Mildred MacNaughton MacKay, Ruth MacNaughton Lewis at Glendenning family reunion. 	First
	Cousins



	

	

	


	
	

	Venetia

	Shickel, Mildred (MacNaughton) MacKay, Ruth (MaNaughton) Lewis
	(Photo taken at a Glendenning Reunion in Point Aux Carr – date not
	known)  One might have guessed they were cousins  even if one did
	not know.
	

	


	
	

	Riddles
	and flails
	

	


	
	

	I
	was reading about PEI manufacturers of early agricultural equipment
	and came across terms not heard very often these days.  
	
	

	


	
	

	Flails
	were
	used to knock seeds and grain (oats, wheat, barley) from their
	stalks or from their pods (peas and beans).  A flail, as I recall,
	was a small pole perhaps 5 feet long with another pole, perhaps 2-3
	feet long tied to one end with a rope or piece of wire.  The only
	time I remember seeing one in use was when Uncle Jim Watling used
	one to “flail” some beans.  Dried bean stocks were put into a
	jute bag and tied then the flail was used to batter it about to
	knock the beans from their pods.
	

	Winnowing
	was
	a way of separating dust and chaff from seeds.  A piece of canvas or
	a sheet was placed on the ground.  With a breeze, a bucket of beans
	was held at high and gently tipped so that the beans dropped to the
	canvas.  Beans being heavy dropped straight down while the chaff and
	dirt blew beyond the canvas.  I remember winnowing peas and beans.
	

	


	
	

	Threshers
	were machines used to strip grain from the straw.
	

	


	
	

	Fanners
	were used to clean the dust, dirt and chaff from grain and other
	seeds.
	

	


	
	

	Riddles
	were found in threshers and fanners; they were screens placed
	horizontally in the thresher or fanner; Riddles shook so that
	smaller seeds dropped through the holes when passing over and larger
	seeds and chaff kept on going. Riddles could be changed depending on
	the kind of seeds to be separated.

	Kenneth Elmer Glendenning
	


	
Ken in
	front yard
	
Ken
	was born on July 25, 1924 and attended the Little Branch School to
	the end of Grade 8.  One year he stayed with Venetia and Cam in
	Point Aux Carr, went to school, and did the chores while Cam fished
	smelts.  He also attended classes in the Bay du Vin Hall and
	graduated from MRHS
	



	
	
In
	October 1939, Ken and I both came down with scarlet fever a week
	apart.  I remember the date because Walter and Agnes came to the
	house and looked in on us the day they were married – November 1,
	1939.  I think the quarantine period was 6 weeks - a red warning
	sign was posted by the front door. We shared the bedroom on the
	ground floor.  Then Ken came down with complications and I was moved
	to the small bedroom upstairs.  That was the time that “Old Jess”,
	our faithful old horse, was put down.
	



	
	
We
	always tapped a few maple trees and Mum made maple syrup.  I went
	with Ken with a horse and sled, with cream cans and the barrel from
	the churn, to collect sap.  As I recall, it was early in the morning
	before we went to school.
	



	
	
Ken
	has stories to tell about Venetia catching him when he tumbled out
	of the car on a turn in the Bathurst Road, getting pecked near an
	eye by a hen, and Wallace MacDonald’s visit to the Little Branch
	school. .  Once on a visit to Bathurst, Ken and I stayed with Aunt
	Maude 
	
	



	
	
In
	1943, Ken enlisted in the RCAF; he phoned Mum from Moncton and, as I
	recall, Walter, Mum and I saw him at the Newcastle station when the
	train stopped briefly.  His first posting was to Toronto fro basic
	training then to Galt fro technical training; later postings
	included St. John’s, Quebec and Scoudouc, New Brunswick.  He

	Follow-up
	



	
	
Donald
	Edge wrote: 
	
	

	


	
	

	“Our
	telephone hung in a box on the wall, and by cranking a handle on one
	side of the box you made a continuous ring in every house in Black
	River. To differentiate homes, our phone was 22--two long and two
	short cranks of the handle. Little Annie MacNaughton was the local
	telephone operator, and of course she got to hear everything, as
	could anyone else who picked up the phone whenever it rang anyone's
	number.  There was a benefit to this, because a continuous cranking
	caused a continuous ringing in all the homes in the area, alerting
	families to a disaster such as a barn on fire, a forest fire, a
	sudden death.
	

	


	
	

	Today
	the phones there are modern and private.  The old MacNaughton house
	now has a street and a number (1008 North Black River Road) and a
	ZIP code (E1N 5T3) and a FAX number, and it has an Internet address
	with photographs.  The telephone number is no longer 22; now it is
	01 46 06 14 74.  Try hand cranking that!”
	

	


	
	
Brakes
	



	
	
Braking
	systems have certainly changed for the better over the years. 
	
	



	
	

	Our
	Model A had mechanical brakes which means that a metal rod linked
	the brake pedal with the brake shoes on each wheel.  Brake shoes
	moved out against the inside of the brake drum when the brakes were
	applied.  Adjustments were possible through a turnbuckle, however,
	it was difficult to have or keep the setting just right with the
	result that it was not unusual for one wheel to have more pressure
	than another.  As a result, cars often swerved if brake pedals were
	jammed hard.  Replacement brake shoes were usually replaced at home.

	Follow-up
	



	
	
Donald
	Edge sent the following follow-up note about aprons:
	



	
	
“Aprons
	have been around for a very long time.  Initially they were uni-sex:
	



	
	
Adam’s
	and Eve’s eyes “were opened, and they knew that they were naked:
	and they sewed the leaves together, and made themselves aprons”
	(Genesis
	3:7).
	



	
	
Curiously,
	the word apron does not appear in the Index and Concordance to the
	King James Bible.
	



	
	
Lots
	of men wore aprons—farriers, glassblowers, and the like, but for
	most of history. aprons were worn by certain women.  The upper
	classes of course did not wear them (although some of their servants
	did). But then the upper classes didn’t use an apron to flap at an
	aggressive farmyard rooster, or to wave in the air to signal someone
	working out in a field.  Until about thirty years ago, practically
	every advertisement for kitchen appliances and household scenes
	featured an elegant slender woman wearing an apron as proof of
	domestic cleanliness and industriousness.

	my experience, more men wear aprons these days, especially when it’s

Remembering

	I believe that I started at

		Ken, Norm and I were at the

		called Norm “Big Glendenning” and called me “Little
		Glendenning”.  
		
	
	



	
	
		


		One
		trick was to place a paper cup full of water on the top edge of a
		almost closed classroom door.  When the door was opened, the cup of

		The

		A

	had some of my slides scanned recently and came across the above

Meat
	
We
	had our own meat, especially in the winter.  We did not have
	electricity, hence no refrigeration although we did have an icehouse
	one year, so the amount and kind of meat varied from season to
	season.  In winter, meat could be kept hanging in the shed with
	portions cut off as needed; in summer when an animal was butchered
	most of it was sold in town or to neighbours but some was kept for
	our own use.  In later years, Norman would butcher a young heifer
	and peddle it from door to door around Black River.  Jack Gibson was
	a butcher and often peddled meat and later Will Harris was a regular
	meat peddler.
	



	
	
Butchering
	was done just inside the large barn doors.  The animal was brought
	to the door and its head held down and steadied with the aid of a
	ring buried in the barn floor.  A sledge hammer or poll axe was used
	to stun the animal then its throat was cut.  Following that, the
	animal would be skinned starting with the hind legs. A short stick,
	a spreader, was used to spread the hind legs and this was attached
	to a set of blocks (pulleys and ropes) so that the animal could be
	hoisted. The butchers continued to skin the animal moving down
	towards the head; from time to time the animal was raised to make it
	easier to skin and to keep the fresh meat from coming in contact
	with the floor.  After skinning, the front of the animal was opened,
	again from top down and the intestines and organs removed.  The
	intestines were dragged to the manure shed or buried.  The heart and
	liver were saved and were considered, at least by me, as a special
	treat.

content_preview:
The
Family
Chronicle

No.
122								              October 27, 2006

____________________________________________________________________



	


	
	

	

	
Vacation
	Bible Class at St. Stephens United Church; undated but probably
	1953-1955. (Glendenning Collection)



	


	
	

	The
	Shantymen
	

	


	
	

	Shantymen
	visited forestry workers and fishermen, and probably others such as
	sailors and trappers bring Christianity (or was it religion?) to
	folk who lived in isolated areas.  I do not recall them ever being
	to Black River but I recall mention of them.  It may well have been
	that either Mother or one of her church organizations contributed to
	the cause from time to time.
	

	


	
	

	Lux
	Daily Dippers
	

	


	
	

	If
	you are a senior, you may have been a “Lux Daily Dipper.”  As I
	recall, the term was a part of a promotion of Lux soap flakes and
	applied, as I recall, to ladies who dipped their undies daily in
	Lux.  
	
	

	


	
	

	Speaking
	of soap, mention was made at our recent family reunion of “Surprise
	Soap”.  As I recall it was an amber coloured translucent hand
	Soap.  Was Sunlight Soap similar?  Then there was carbolic soap,
	Lifebuoy (was it a deep pink or orange in colour?), Naptha which
	didn’t seem to stay around very long, and for really dirty hands,
	there was lava soap which contained pumice which is the fine ask
	from a volcano.  (Pumice was, and perhaps still is, used for
	smoothing the finishes of fine furniture.)
	

	


	
	

	Radio
	Programs
	

	


	
	

	I
	was with a group a few nights ago, that was reminiscing about radio
	programs.  Here are a few I recall or that were mentioned:  Gabriel
	Heater and the news (WOR); the Lone Ranger, Amos and Andy, the Green
	Hornet, WWVA Wheeling, West Virginia for country music; the Maritime
	Gardener, Gillette Friday night Boxing; Don Messer and the
	Islanders; Dagwood and Blondie (or in the words of a neighbour,

Extensive personal essay by Donald Edge ("Faith of our Fathers") describing childhood religious experience: mandatory Sunday attendance (aisle 14), hymn singing ("Onward Christian Soldiers," "Old Rugged Cross"), summer Sunday school, Bible verse memorization, hand pump organ music. Details cultural significance of shoes (worn only weekends/church), cemetery visits overlooking Black River with familiar gravesites and erosion concerns. Concludes with poignant retrospective: "postcard winters and endless golden summers" and "people I loved then as I love them now." 	Pigtails,
	etc
	

	

	
I
	am at the “clean-up” stage of life and came across some of my
	early handiwork.  I am sure that many readers could do the same.
	



	
	
Sometime
	between September 1949 and June 1951 I learned to twist and solder
	pigtails; I forgot all about it until I came across a soldering pot
	among my mementos. The above photo shows the soldering pot with the
	wire handle.
	



	
	
In
	those days electricians made joints by twisting the ends of wires
	together; these joints were called pigtails and they were commonly
	used in house wiring.  The wires were then coated with resin so that
	the solder would stick.  Because many electrical connections were in
	the ceiling boxes, a normal soldering iron was difficult to use. 
	Instead one heated the soldering pot with a blow torch and then
	pushed it up so that the pigtail was immersed in the solder.
	



	
	
I
	made the soldering pot shown in the photo using a pipe coupling with
	a plug screwed into one end and then machined level.  The handle is
	a piece of welding rod.  The soldering pot would swivel as it was
	raised to the ceiling.  Today, wires are joined with connectors.
	



	
	
The
	policeman, a lawn ornament, was made in 1944 while a student at
	MRHS.
	



	
	
The
	C-clamp and the Vee block were hand made also and part of my
	training while at the New Brunswick Technical Institute in
	1949-1951.  At that time I was learning to become an industrial arts
	teacher.

	A&R

	The
	A&R Loggie Co. was incorporated in 1881 at Black Brook, later
	renamed Loggieville.  As I recall, Aunt Tine said that Andrew

	They
	were exporters of salmon, smelts, trout, haddock, etc and also

	and laths, was a large operation and took up all of the space on the

	central cashier; clerks at the counter made up the bill, stuffed the

	was whisked across the store to the  cashier who checked the bill,
	made change and returned the bill and change to the clerk.  
	
	

	


	
	

	In
	Loggieville alone, the company employed about 150 workers.  Part of
	a worker’s pay packet was a credit that had to be used at their
	store. 
	
	

	


	
	

	In

	blueberries. Once when travelling with Brydone to Bathurst, he drove

	groceries,

title: Family Chronicle No. 131: Case tractors at the show at
summary: Three thematic sections. First: Argyle Shore (PEI) annual farm tractor show featuring 100+ working machines (no pre-WWII vintage). Second: lyrical personal essay on transparent apples—semi-ripe pale green fruit from lone orchard tree (MacNaughton property), crispness and tartness superior to fully ripe white specimens, bounty exceeded Don's consumption, fallen fruit worthless. Plea to readers to locate similar trees (will travel by July for taste). Third: historical note on "turnpiking" (grandfather Glendenning turnpiked Canobie-Springfield road); internet sources conflate toll-collecting with road-making. Wages and costs in 1915 (Fighting 26th Battalion, CEF): Warrant Officer $2.50/day, Sergeant $1.50, Corporal $1.20, Private $1.10; soldiers could assign 80% pay to relatives; bread 5¢/lb, beef 13¢/lb, mutton 15¢/lb; no income tax. Funeral customs history: home wakes, two-day visitations (now reduced), neighbor assistance, purple banner at door, winter transport by sled, brief eulogies (sermons dominant), hand-dug graves, sandy Black River Cemetery soil facilitated winter burial. Rich social history and personal memoir.

The
Family

No.

____________________________________________________________________


	


	
	

	

	

	Case tractors at the show at
	

	Argyle Shore, PEI
	



	
	
Folks
	along the Argyle shore in PEI  put on an annual farm tractor show; I
	went this year for the first time.  There were over 100 working farm
	tractors on display. The above shows a row of Cockshutt tractors but
	there were many other makes as well.  None of the tractors were
	pre-WW2 vintage.
	



	
	



	
	
Transparent
	apples – Mmmm good
	

	


	
	

	"Comfort me with
	apples…" (Song
	of Solomon)
	

	


	
	

	An almost ripe transparent
	apple is the best thing I have ever eaten.  Almost ripe transparents
	were a pale green; fully ripe in August they were almost white, but
	by then they had lost some of the tart crispness I so much enjoyed.
	I did my best to keep any transparent apple from ripening, but the
	bounty of that lone tree in the small MacNaughton orchard beside the
	house was truly amazing, and there were always a great many green
	apples that escaped me and grew to maturity. Once they had fallen
	from the tree they were of no interest to me--they were too white,
	too mushy.
	

	


	
	

	There were other apple trees,
	but only the one transparent. It was an old tree when I first knew
	it, and over the years I saw it produce less and less, and then it
	was gone.  I have never seen another one, although I have looked. If
	any reader knows of one, I beg you to contact me immediately,
	preferably by July.  I will go wherever I must go to eat of the
	fruit of that tree.  One bite and I will be in Eden, in the paradise
	as I remember it, of summer boyhood down home.
	

	


	
	

	Donald Edge

	term “turnpike” is used to denote the making of a new road.  In

title: Family Chronicle No. 133: Little Branch School, 1929
summary: Multiple sections. Photographs: Little Branch School (1929) and Cameron School (1933) by teacher Annie May Loggie (courtesy Della Adams O'Neill). Genealogy project announcement: Don has compiled 60+ years of family research (both paternal and maternal sides) and completed publication; intends to present copy to Chatham Library upon next Miramichi visit. Whittling essay (by Donald Edge): father was accomplished whittler; Edge possesses three sharp pocketknives and lidless gum box (book-shaped, bearing initials JME, held hardened spruce resin/gum). Men carried "Barlow" pocket knives for tobacco, twine-cutting, apple-peeling, mumblety-peg. Black River whittling culture reduced sticks to toothpicks under Protestant work ethic. Doreen (Glendenning) Nicol contributed: 1930s-1970s automobile features (fender skirts, running boards, Continental kits, dyna-flow transmissions, rumble seats, curb feelers, manual cranks, side-mounted tires, non-permanent antifreeze, hydraulic brakes, tire repairs). Early Black River vehicles: Gordon Adams first red car, Jessie Adams roadster, Alex MacDonald's Oakland, Model A power tools, spring trucks post-fishing season. Technological innovations: gravity-fed gas tanks, vacuum wipers, lift-up hood panels, aftermarket direction signals (Don's 1952 Dodge with Canadian Tire signals), A&R Loggie Goderson trucks, Arnie Watling's post-war red Chevrolet mail truck. Comprehensive material culture and automotive history. Significant family/biographical content and documentation of Don's long genealogical work.

title: Family Chronicle No. 134: My Great Grandmother was Margaret Harley; her sister, Mary Ann Harley was interviewed by a newspaper
summary: Don publishes an extended newspaper interview (dated 99th birthday, 1898) featuring his great-aunt Mary Ann Harley Henry, who emigrated from Ireland to the Miramichi region in 1822. Her vivid account covers living through the Napoleonic Wars, the arrival of the first steamship in Irish waters (1822), the harrowing 7-week transatlantic voyage to Pockshaw (Bay of Chaleur), and a 75-mile wilderness trek through uncut forest to Newcastle. She married John Henry and had nine children; lived 99 years (1799-1898). Don includes scholarly follow-up from cousin Kelsie Erskine exploring the family's motivations for emigration and their Irish social standing during this period. Rich ancestral context for the Glendenning family's Miramichi roots.

Don's parents (Grace and Walter) and siblings (Venetia, Lillian) lived on the base; their daughter Margaret is buried in St. John's Episcopal Cemetery. title: Family Chronicle No. 141: Smelt Fishing
summary: Detailed first-person account of winter smelt fishing on the Miramichi (ca. 1950 photo shows Bill Taylor, Eldred and Cameron Russell). Don explains the technical operation of box nets, leaders, ice holes, toggle sticks, and the demanding work of hauling nets twice daily at tide changes. Describes the loading, freezing, and transport of smelts by sleigh. Names buyers including Uncle Jim Watling (buyer for W.S. Loggie Company, Chatham) and A & R Loggie Company (Loggieville). Explains how fishermen stayed on the ice all week with horses and shanties. Notes the practice of dropping nets to the riverbed during ice runs. This is a colorful portrait of Miramichi working life and local family connections (Watling family involvement).

	Smelt
	Fishing
	

	


	
	

	

	

	


	
	

	

	
Above
	we see Bill Taylor (standing) with Eldred and Cameron Russell
	tending their fishing nets off the Point Aux Carr shore.  The exact
	year is unknown, however, it would be around 1950. Although my
	family did not fish, here is my under- standing of how winter smelt
	fishing with box nets worked.
	

	


	
	

	Smelt fishermen on the
	Miramichi still set box nets, usually double, through the winter ice
	in the same way as they have for perhaps 100 years or more.  While
	the fishing method is the same, “Old Dobbin” has been replaced
	by snowmobiles and four wheelers.  
	
	

	


	
	

	A box net, as the name
	suggests, is a rectangular box about 14 feet wide and fifty feet
	long; the depth varies depending on the depth of the water.  The
	mesh is slightly under an inch compared with a salmon net where the
	mesh is about five inches.
	

	


	
	

	A flat piece of netting,
	called a leader, juts out from each side of the net for a distance
	of 100 feet.  Since smelts swim against the current, the leader is
	placed across the current and helps guide fish into the net.  Fish
	come to the leader and, if they turn the right way, in attempting to
	swim around the net find themselves trapped in the “box” part of
	the net.  The net is designed for easy entrance; once inside,
	however, it is almost impossible for a smelt to swim out.  The
	entire net is placed under the ice.  
	
	

	


	
	

	The photos show a slot, a
	smelt hole, in the ice up to 14 feet long and maybe 15 inches wide. 
	Smelt holes were cut using an ice saw, now a chain saw, and kept
	clear with a chisel as needed.
	

	The centre of the box net is
	placed directly under this hole and, anchored to toggle sticks, a
	forked stick frozen into the ice close to the smelt hole.

	also need to be anchored.  Firs...

Features a personal reflection on red ochre paint stored in a barn workshop—a cheap farm paint mixed with linseed oil used for rural buildings. Describes the wagons shed at Don's family farm, the Model A stored during the Depression, and tools for farm equipment repair. Provides material culture context for rural life during Don's childhood/young adulthood.

title: Family Chronicle No. 146: A view of Black River from space
summary: Don draws on Arnold J. Somers' memoir of 1920s-1940s Miramichi lumbering. Includes period wage data ($1.50/day in 1939-40), production figures (3.5-5,000 board feet per crew daily), and social history (poll taxes, road taxes, "statute labour," poor houses in Chatham). Reflects on haywire as the "duct tape of my era" for farm repairs. Reader Donald Edge contributes etymology of local island names (Fox Island = "Île au Pendu," Bay du Vin = "Baie des Ovines"). Discusses chimney fires and creosote buildup—practical knowledge from Don's adult housekeeping. Links Don's personal experience to broader regional economic and social history of the Depression and post-war era.

summary: Personal memoir of southernwood plants (admired by local Alex Newton), mystery regarding a Baptist Church in Black River (possibly on present St. Paul's Presbyterian site or across the road), and legends of graves behind the church. Includes genealogical explanation of "once removed" kinship (Danny Glendenning is first cousin once removed; Uncle Harry Glendenning joke about "49th cousins"). Includes reader feedback from Art Mills about school bus driver Clifford Adams's patience with noisy students and an anecdote about Mills reading sports books instead of schoolwork. Quotes Chatham Gazette (1932) on a Dominion Department of Agriculture experimental farm at Walter Cameron's, Black River Bridge under T. G. Hetherington's supervision. Blends personal memory, family history, and local archive.

In

A

	southernwood - as do I.

title: Family Chronicle No. 148: Black River Households
summary: Comprehensive census-like listing of Black River households in 1939, updated and expanded from Newsletter 61. Lists neighbors by location (Little Branch Bridge, bridges, schools, churches, community hall) with family names and some occupations. Over 100 households documented, including Watlings, Fowlies, MacDonalds, Camerons, Gibsons, and others. Compiled with assistance from Harold MacLean, Jack Wilson, Don Edge, and George Watling. Don notes anomalies in naming conventions (single Kelly home vs. multiple Watling households). Explicitly solicits reader corrections and additions to build a complete, accurate census. A valuable genealogical artifact and community history snapshot of Don's childhood neighborhood.

The Family Chronicle

No. 152									  February 2, 2008

____________________________________________________________________

 As I pointed out in the last Newsletter, William Harley, 1796-1838, came to Canada in 1820 and was a surveyor.  After 10 years, he decided to leave New Brunswick for “greener pastures”.  In 1930, he traveled to Ontario to scout opportunities there.  Thanks to Heather Hess, a direct descendent of William Harley; I am reprinting a letter from William Harley written to his wife while traveling to Ontario to scout opportunities there.




“St. John’s, New Brunswick - Tuesday, November 28, 1832



My dearest, dearest wife:



I write you to let you know that I take my departure from this town tomorrow morning for Eastport in the steam packet.  I arrived here last Thursday morning from Fredericton and at first engaged in a passage direct to New York in a brig.  She sailed yesterday, my friends having advised me to the contrary.  I did not go in her, and it is well, as last night there arose a most tremendous storm which still continued and she is now rocking about the Bay of Fundy, the Lord only knows where.



I called on the Nashwaak as I came over but found only the old lady and John at home.  Archy was in the woods and the rest were visiting.  I wrote you from Bois’s by Willard who promised to take the key of the office which I took away by mistake and left at Nat Moer’s.  I also sent you two five pound notes by Blake who promised to deliver them through Nathaniel Sprague to you, which also remained with me thro’; mistake in my pocket book.  My dearest girl, I have ever since felt so homesick, especially among strangers, that I scarcely think of what I am doing.  Let me request of you for heaven’s sake to let yourself or our dear little ones want for nothing whatever.  I have spoken to Taylor who promised at the shortest notice to supply you with any money you may have occasion for and also, my dear, console yourself and let not my absence g...
