Origin of Watling Name




It is thought that the Watlings were Vikings who landed in Northern Scotland in 870 AD, invaded northern France in 910 AD and then came to England with William the Conqueror in 1066.  The name is found in the Domesday Book which was a census taken in England in 1086. The first record of the name Watling was found in Sussex, England somewhere between London and Dover.  It is likely that the name arises from Wartling which was a hamlet in the area but others believe that it was associated with Watling Road. By the time of Richard 1, the Watling name had spread north to Watlingford in Oxfordshire, Watlington in Norfolk, Essex and Hertfordshire.  Many Norman families moved north to Scotland in the 12th century and this might have included some Watlings.




The Roger Watling Website includes the following comments about the origin of the Watlings:




"In the 5th/6th century a band of people crossed the North Sea from Europe to the British Isles, we do not know if it was one or more boats, but as a yachtsman sailing these waters I would suppose the latter, there being safety in numbers.  They knew where they were going as trading was and had taken place long before, also they would have had oral stories from their forbearers who might have served in the Roman Legions, without a shred of evidence I like to think that they were Angles, or possibly Jute in origin rather than Saxon.  The leader of this band was WACEAL, and those with him of the same clan, tribe or group were the Waceal - ingas.  Ingas was not the son of as in the Scottish Watson, but meaning people of or followers of Waceal, so members of this group would be referred to as Wacelaingas.  As time past the name began to change from, the vowels hardening, or softening, plus the input of people from other tongues and one form was...

Editor’s Note: This is the second of three Newsletters dealing primarily with my Watling roots; some of the information is a repeat but some is also new.




 Jubal and Susanna (Leach) Watling




Tess Barker, Watling Genealogy Group, reports finding "Metfield marriage: Jubal Watling singleman of Brockdish, Norfolk and Susan Leech, singlewoman, of this parish by banns, 10th November, 1814.  Jubal signed (good handwriting) and Susan marked.  Witnesses:  Shemus Leech  and Peter Archor.




The comment about handwriting is more significant than one might think because it indicates a level of literacy.  According to some internet discussions, the Watlings were thought to be labourers and, when I reported a Jubal as a “mason” in PEI,   the group was quite skeptical.  Seeing his actual handwriting, made them think otherwise.




Family lore says that the Watlings came from England to Prince Edward Island and eventually some moved to Black River, near Chatham, New Brunswick - but we have no record of Jubal and Susanna in New Brunswick.  




My first search on PEI turned up some Watlings but insufficient information to make a family connection.  With new information about the family generally, however, I searched again for a PEI connection and have changed my mind.  




The census of 1841, shows a Jubal Watling, living in Lot 52, PEI; Lot 52 is in eastern PEI close to Montague and Georgetown; there were 6 people in the household, four of whom were born in England and two in PEI; of the six in the household, four males were under age sixteen, one female between 16 and 45 and one male between 45 and 60; the census records also show that Jubal was a mason and that one of the six had paid his or her passage.

title: Family Chronicle No. 159: Islands of the Miramichi
summary: An exploration of the geography and history of Fox Island and other barrier islands at the mouth of the Miramichi River, including Portage, Egg, Huckleberry, Hay, and Neguac Beach islands. Don describes his father's ownership of a marsh on Fox Island and recounts a personal anecdote about making hay there, transporting it by sled behind a Model A car to Little Branch Bridge, then by horse to the barn. The issue discusses the narrow, winding navigation channels and Don's research into floating marshes and historical land-use practices.

	Islands
	of the Miramichi



	I
	lived for many years on the Miramichi and, while I knew that there
	were Islands at the mouth, I always thought that incoming ships and
	even fishing boats could travel most anywhere; that is not the case.
	 I am beholden to Lynn Gregan for the nautical geography lesson and
	now realize how narrow and winding the entrance channel really is.  
	
	
	

	The
	inner Miramichi Bay is separated from the outer Bay by a line of
	uninhabited barrier
	islands.
	The inner bay measures only 4 m deep on average, with the navigation
	channel measuring only 6-10 m. The Miramichi Bay is no longer
	dredged; therefore, the ports of Chatham and Newcastle (Miramichi)
	are only accessible to ships with a shallow draft.
	

	Fox
	Island,
	5-6 miles in length, was probably named after the British statesman
	Charles James Fox (1749-1806). is the longest with the closest point
	being to the East of Baie Ste Anne and about a mile off shore. It
	has long been the site of commercial fishing operations.
	

	


	
	

	Portage
	Island

	Island which was cut in two by a large storm.

title: Family Chronicle No. 160: Glenelg Parish and Black River in the 1851 Census
summary: A detailed analysis of the 1851 Northumberland County Census for Glenelg Parish and Black River, compiled by Donald Edge. The census recorded 281 households with settlers predominantly Scottish and Irish, arriving in the 1820s-1830s. The article catalogs occupations (farmers, fishermen, weavers, teachers), identifies unusual settler names, and documents health challenges and absences. Don's ancestors Alexander and Jane MacNaughton appear as farmers with daughter teachers, while Jubal Watling and Christina appear in household records. The issue concludes with Don's reflection on beech nuts and autumn walks along the family farm's wooded ridge.

No. 160										  July 7, 2008

Glenelg Parish and Black River in the 1851 Census

By Donald Edge, November 2001




The 1851 Northumberland County Census is the earliest record of  households in Glenelg Parish.  The Census contains the names of family members, their sex, relationship, age,  national origin, occupation, religion (if known) and their date of arrival in what was then a colony.  Researchers have noted that the Glenelg Census was often inaccurate.* Compilers of the  printed version assigned house numbers, and these are included in the following to simplify research reference .




There were 281 households in Glenelg, compared with 501 in Chatham.  The  majority of Glenelg settlers were Scots and Irish, followed by French, English, Welsh, and a smattering  from Shetland, Portugal, USA, and the Isle of Man. Houses #77 and #78 were located in the Fox Island Establishment.** 




Most of the settlers arrived in the 1820s and 1830s. The earliest settler identified in the Glenelg Census is widow Sarah McIntyre (house #59), who arrived from America in 1774.  Widow Isabella McInnes (#88) arrived from Scotland in 1778. The oldest resident was   88 year old widow Elizabeth McKnight in house # 158,   the youngest was one month old Barbara MacDonald  in house #69.




While there were many labourers, and remarkably quite a few servants, the great majority were farmers, although some had a   sideline.  There was one farmer who was also a cooper (barrel-maker), one lighthouse keeper (Escuminac), one mason, two carpenters, two millers, two proprietors, three joiners, five shoemakers, seven teachers,  eight lumberers,  nine fishermen, ten river pilots, and ten weavers.  John McDonald (house #123) was a fisherman and Magistrate.

title: Family Chronicle No. 162: History of the Apron:
summary: Family Chronicle essay on the history and utility of grandma's apron reflecting on rural domestic life and female contributions to household economy. Nostalgic piece fitting Don's broader project documenting community heritage.
content_preview:
The Family Chronicle

No. 162									   October 5, 2008

____________________________________________________________________

  

History of the Apron:




This as sent to me some time ago but unfortunately, I cannot remember by whom. 

 

The principal use of Grandma's apron was to protect the dress underneath, but along with that, it served as a potholder for removing hot pans from the oven.




It was wonderful for drying children's tears, and on occasionally was even used for cleaning out dirty ears.




From the chicken coop, the apron was used for carrying eggs, fussy chicks, and sometimes half-hatched eggs to be finished in the warming oven.




When company came, those aprons were ideal hiding places for shy kids.




And when the weather was cold, grandma wrapped it around her arms.




Those big old aprons wiped many a perspiring brow, bent over the hot wood stove.




Chips and kindling wood were brought into the kitchen in that apron.




From the garden, it carried all sorts of vegetables. After the peas had been shelled, it carried out the hulls.




In the fall, the apron was used to bring in apples that had fallen from the trees.




When unexpected company drove up the road, it was surprising how much furniture that old apron could dust in a matter of seconds.




When dinner was ready, Grandma walked out onto the porch, waved her apron, and the men knew it was time to come in from the fields to dinner




It will be a long time before someone invents something that will replace that 'old-time apron' that served so many purposes




Send this to those who would know, and love the story about Grandma's aprons.




REMEMBER:




Grandma used to set her hot baked apple pies on the window sill to cool




Her granddaughters set theirs on the window sill to thaw.




They would go crazy now trying to figure out how many germs were on that apron.




I don't think I ever caught anything from an apron.

title: Family Chronicle No. 169: An undated photograph of “Edythe Watlin” from Caryl Savard
summary: Don's speculative genealogical research on Jubal Watling (born 1790, married Susan Leach in 1814), who Don believed moved to Prince Edward Island after Susan's death in England in 1829. Using PEI records of a second marriage to Louisa in 1831, census data, and photographs from researcher Caryl Savard, Don constructs a theory that Charles Watling (born 1846-47) could be Jubal's son with Louisa, making Edythe and Ambrose Watling his grandchildren. Don acknowledges the circumstantial but plausible nature of this connection, noting Jubal's age and the tight timeline present challenges to verification.

title: Family Chronicle No. 170: Recognize this view of Black River??
summary: Family Chronicle on local Black River postcards, history of haywire/binder twine terminology, and rural farm equipment. Reflects Don's interest in material culture and linguistic history of agricultural community.
content_preview:
The
Family
Chronicle

No.
170									     March 6, 2009

____________________________________________________________________








	

	

	Recognize this view of
	Black River??
	

	


	
	

	Barry Mackenzie, “a
	collector of local postcards, and this one was generously given to
	me by Joan Menzies of Miramichi from her own collection…“wonders
	if readers know where this was taken?  Barry also wonders if readers
	know of other Black River postcards of yesteryear.  If you have one,
	send me a copy and I will publish it in a future Chronicle.
	

	 



	  Haywire and
	binder twine
	

	


	
	

	In a  recent issue of the
	Chronicle, I noted the price of binder twin as 90 cents a ball in
	1942 with a ball being a bit larger than a 1kg coffee can but, of
	course, much heavier.
	

	


	
	

	Early settlers cut grain with
	scythe and sickle; a major breakthrough occurred in 1831 with the
	invention of the McCormick reaper in Virginia.  The advent of the
	binder forty years later resulted in grain being cut and bundled
	then dropped on the ground.  The twine used in the binder became
	known as binder twine.  Early binder twine was made of sisal, a
	natural product, which was biodegradable.  The combine replaced the
	binder and threshes the grain as it harvests; binder twine is not
	needed.
	

	


	
	

	The advent of the hay baler,
	however, provided a new need for twine, baler twine, much of which
	is synthetic.  Baler twine is, I believe, much heavier than binder
	twine.  
	
	

	A quick search of the
	internet also tells me:  
	
	

	


	
	

	‘Haywire
	is a compound of the words hay
	and wire,
	originally simply denoting wire used to bale hay or straw. The term
	is first recorded as a noun in a debate in the Canadian House of
	Commons (1917), so it is a Canadianism or, since it appeared soon
	thereafter in a U.S. publication, a North Americanism. We find an
	earlier (1905) attributive use in the phrase hay
	wire outfit,
	a term used contemptuously for poorly equipped loggers....

	Whiffle Tree
	

	


	
	

	A horse collar was fitted
	over a horses head and, in effect, was the part of the harness used
	to pull a wagon or sled.  The actual connection to the wagon or
	implement was a set of traces.  The part of a wagon or implement
	where the traces connected was called a whiffle tree, (sometimes
	called a whipple tree).   
	
	

	


	
	

	A whiffle trees is a piece of
	hardwood, perhaps thirty inches long to which the traces are
	fastened.  The whiffletree, in turn, is attached to the wagon or
	implement by a clevis so it could pivot.  A team of horses required
	two whiffletrees; a three horse team required three whiffletrees
	with a special arrangement to give each an horse equal leverage.

	The old fashioned way
	

	


	
	

	

	

	Recently I was part of a tour of the collection of early
	agricultural equipment owned by Dr. Roy Montgomery, Birch Hill, PEI.
	 Although of post-war vintage, this Farmall Cub farm tractor
	required a crank and elbow grease to start.
	

	


	
	
From
	a wartime newspaper
	



	
	
The
	Commercial of September 16, 1943 carried the following:
	



	
	
“Peanut
	butter, jelly powders and soya bean spreads are not included in the
	list of rationed sweet spreads such as jams, jellies, molasses and
	such products.  Ration book holders who do not wish to purchase
	these rationed commodities may use the “D” coupons to buy sugar.
	 Each “D” coupon allows the consumer to buy one-half pound of
	sugar.”
	

	


	
	

	


	
	
Who
	remembers the Tucker?
	 
	
	

	


	
	

	

	

	


	
	
According
	to Wikapedia, the Tucker was designed in Michigan and built in
	Chicago in 1948; only 51 were ever built of which 48 still survive. 
	
	
	



	
	
Named
	after Preston Tucker, the car had 3 headlamps, a torpedo like front
	end and the engine in the rear.  It also had a padded dash, seat
	belts, and pop out windshield.   The Tucker used a unibody
	construction meaning that the body was welded to the frame in order
	to eliminate body rattles.  The frame was shaped like a ship's prow
	at the front and rear which was supposed to make it stronger. The
	bumpers were mounted on springs to absorb shock in a crash, and
	because of the weight balance provided by the rear mounted engine
	the brakes would wear evenly and the car would lower itself evenly,
	instead of the front end pitching down, in panic stops. The rims
	were also designed so that if one of the tires went flat, the car
	wouldn't pull dramatically to that side.

A

On
	July 21, 1914, Elmer and Jane (Watling) Glendenning purchased the
	“Jessie MacDonald” property at Little Branch; the property was
	one-half of the original grant (225 acres) to Alexander MacDonald on
	June 3, 1812, who on his death, bequeathed half to his daughter,
	Jessie, and the other half to his son, John.  On Jessie’s death,

	sold it to my parents.
	



	
	
The
	original house was a traditional 11/2 story with the gable end
	toward the road (See far end of house in photo above.)  Sometime
	after 1919, Dad added the ell towards the lane and a full verandah
	across the front. Lumber for the addition, including hardwood for
	the floors and pine for the pantry cabinets, was cut on the
	property.  (The part of the verandah across the front of the
	original house has since been removed.)  The back entry was added in
	recent years.
	
There
	was a small barn on the property at time of purchase.  Again,
	probably in the 1920’s, Dad doubled the length of the barn and put
	a shed along the complete length on the side next the River.
	



	
	
Norman
	took over the operation of the farm after getting out of the
	service, and since then has modernized the house, modernized and
	added to the barn, added the sheds and built the silos.  It is

	 Name, History, 1840

	Glenelg in geography is one
	of the most common palindromes, a name that reads the same backwards
	and forwards. The original Glenelg in the highlands of Scotland is
	both a village and a mountainous peninsula and a bay in Ross-Shire
	that look across the Sound of Sleat to the Isle of Skye.  This
	highland name Glenelg is said to derive from the Gaelic Gleann
	Seilg, the Glen of
	Hunting.  
	
	

	


	
	

	There are many other
	Glenelgs, including a Glenelg village and lake in Nova Scotia, and a
	Glenelg in Ontario.  In the 1830's Lord Glenelg was England's

title: Family Chronicle No. 190: MacLaughlin driving wagon, early 1900’s
summary: Family Chronicle #190 (September 2010) features nostalgic recollections of 1920s-era transportation, a MacLaughlin wagon exhibit, and an in memoriam poem, reflecting Don's personal memories of rural community life and family history.
content_preview:
The
Family
Chronicle


No.
190									 September 3, 2010


	

	

	MacLaughlin driving wagon,
	early 1900’s
	



	
	
The
	wagon pictured above was found on the second floor of the Gill
	Carriage shop in Eliotvale, PEI.  The wagon, although no nameplate
	was found, is believed to be manufactured by the MacLaughlin Company
	of Ontario (later the MacLaughlin Buick Motor Company) driving
	wagon. The wagon is owned by John Gill who, along with his father,
	was a carriage maker, ceasing the business sometime after WW2.  The
	wagon belonged to Mr. Gill’s brother and, John recalls, was
	imported by his brother from Ontario in the 1920’s.
	



	
	
The
	wagon, pictured above, reminds me of our light driving wagon when I
	grew up.  Some wagons had a solid back; ours, as I recall, had an
	open back like the one pictured above.  Ours also had a hinged cover
	on the portion of the box behind the seat to keep parcels out of
	sight but also to keep them dry
	



	
	
Given
	the size of our family, for church, we usually traveled in an

title: Family Chronicle No. 192: Church Union
summary: Family Chronicle #192 analyzes the 1925 Church Union that divided Presbyterian congregations in Black River, explaining historical context and theological divisions that affected Don's community and shaped local institutional memory.
content_preview:
The Family Chronicle

No. 192 _______________________________________________________________

 Church Union




I’ve avoided mentioning church union of 1925; however, it was a significant event and one that strained relationships in Black River for many years.  I’ve decided to avoid it no longer.  Tensions were evident when I was young, and may well exist among some of the older generation even today.  The decision even split some families




Here is my understanding based on my personal knowledge and experience, a master’s thesis by John Cameron about church union in Pictou, Nova Scotia, and a book in 1985, Resistance to Church Union  by Clifford Keith.




Divisions within the Presbyterian Church in Scotland, it seems, went on forever.  Most resulted from differing views as to the proper or acceptable relationship between church and state.  Scots were not prepared to accept a state church, as was the case in England.  Perhaps another cause for dissension was the strong view that no minister or church hierarchy should stand between a person and his/her God.   Then there was the issue of churches being able to appoint their own minister rather than have a minister appointed by the land owner or proprietor, or some other church body.  By 1843 there were four different Presbyterian churches in Scotland – and Scots brought their differing views with them when they came to Canada.  The early mid -1800’s witnessed a movement towards unification among a number of Presbyterian denominations that resulted, by 1875, in the creation of the Presbyterian Church in Canada - and discussions with other Presbyterians continued.




Other denominations were coming together as well.  Union within the Methodist denomination was achieved by 1884 and within the Congregationalist churches by 1906.  The Church of England, as early as 1836, had appointed a committee to explore possible union with like-minded denominations.  Talk of further unification, therefore, was not unexpected.  In ...

content_preview:

 Neighbours/People/Characters:




There always seemed to be something going on at our house.  This was partly because we were a large family and active in the community, but also because my father, as Secretary Treasurer of Agricultural Society #103, operated the “store” for its members.  People from Black River and neighbouring communities came to our place to pick up farm supplies.




The following names have stayed in my memory:




Uncle Bob and Aunt Bioney MacDougall – although called Uncle  and Aunt, were not actually related. Their original home, I believe, was on the Point beyond Harper’s, or in the very long lane across from, and just below, Jim Cameron’s.  Later they moved to Hexham corner and kept the Post Office 

Charlie Blizzard – lived in Loggieville but later moved to the Bush Smith house across from the Miramichi Rural High School. He was a well known character, with a yard cluttered with machinery and a long beard.  

Fred MacLean  known for his  dry wit; 

Will Harris, from Glenwood, was a butcher and peddled meat around Black River from the back of his truck – a green International ½ ton as I recall

Jack Gibson – was a tall and big-boned, ruddy faced man.  For years he delivered mail around Black River.  In winter he used a sled on which he built a light frame which was covered with unbleached cotton, with an “ising glass” window, to protect him from the cold.  A slot in the front allowed the reins to pass through. title: Family Chronicle No. 196: Typical Community Events
summary: Family Chronicle #196 (October 2010) describes community events—school closings, church harvest festivals, local celebrations—illustrating the social and cultural fabric of Don's childhood in 1930s-40s Miramichi.
content_preview:
The Family Chronicle

No. 196									   October 24, 2010

____________________________________________________________________

 

Typical Community Events




School closings – the Little Branch School, like other one-room schools, held both a Christmas and June school closing; the public was invited to both.  The school was swept and tidied up, Christmas or floral designs were stenciled on the blackboards and student names and standing by grade were also listed on the blackboard.  Then there was singing (no piano) recitations and skits organized so that every student had a role.  I imagine that Santa Claus visited although I cannot really recall it.  There was fudge and Christmas candy for all.  We must have exchanged gifts but again, I do not recall and there would be a gift for teacher.




MRHS – By 1940, there was also a Christmas concert and June graduation at the Miramichi Rural High School.  The Christmas concert usually included items from each of the 8 feeder schools plus a pageant or play by high school students.  Unlike the feeder schools, the high school had electric lights (so the function could be held at night) and a real stage with curtains.




For the graduation, the auditorium was decorated with blueflags.  During the morning of the gradation, the school bus would take us to an area where we picked blueflags (below Jim Cameron’s, as I recall).  Seems to me that we also had some cedar boughs.  The graduation program included a valedictorian the reading of a class will and a speaker from the community. The graduation was followed by a dance. (Would any reader have a copy of a class will?)







Harvest Home – On Labour Day, St. Stephens United Church organized a festival and fund-raiser called the Harvest Home; it was first held in 1890.  People came from miles around to enjoy the event and to meet old friends.  There were games for both young and adults and, of course, a delicious dinner, usually salmon and turkey? – and all the food was home-c...

title: Family Chronicle No. 198: From Donald Edge
summary: Family Chronicle #198 (November 2010) features historian Donald Edge's commentary on family anecdotes and local history, plus Don's recollection of music from his childhood—hymns and popular songs that soundtrack his early memories.
content_preview:
The Family Chronicle

No. 198									November 4, 2010

____________________________________________________________________

From Donald Edge



There is a family story that Duncan MacNaughton (1787-1824) was going down the Black River on a raft of logs and commented that Alexander Gunn's Point would be a wonderful place for a cemetery. Not long after he was killed by a falling tree while clearing his land on the Little Branch back road.  He was the second person buried in the common burial ground on Gunn's Point that was owned by Enoch Godfrey and that was to become the site of St. Stephen's cemetery.  The first buried there was Robert MacBeath in 1823.



There was indeed a gravel pit immediately west of John W's.  I don't know the ownership--possibly Rankin MacLean--but lots of different folks would get gravel there, and MacNaughton household children would play there on the way to and from school. It was especially popular during pollywog season.  After  John W's death and the closing of the sawmill, much of the land on the north side of the road became a giant gravel pit to feed construction needs for miles around. The area looked like a moonscape; the sight brought tears to the eyes of my Uncle Mac.



I spent a lot of time at Rankin MacLean's --Marvin was my very best friend   I also went next door to see Ramsay--his home was spartan bare and very clean.  Ramsay chewed tobacco and had badly stained teeth, and he was fond of giving ladies young and old a kiss on the lips, something that the ladies quickly learned to ward off.




Music 




While Carol and I were attending a concert recently, I remembered that I had not mentioned music in my Chronicles.  Although I checked some of the titles, I remember every one of the songs listed.  I also recall WWVA, Wheeling, West Virginia; CFCY, Charlottetown; and a station in Quebec.  Don’t just look at the titles, hum each tune.
